SENT.plain: A 30-year-old Japanese male, who had no remarkable family history, visited our hospital with a complaint of abdominal pain, and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and hyperamylasemia were observed

He showed negative hemolysis tests, positive nicotinic acid test, low hepatic bilirubin UDP-glucuronyltransferase activity, decreased bilirubin diglucuronide and increased bilirubin monoglucuronide in bile, and a decrease in serum bilirubin after phenobarbital administration
He also showed high serum amylase level, low urine amylase level, and low amylase-creatinine clearance ratio
Gel filtration of serum with Sephadex G-200 revealed the existence of macroamylase
Countercurrent immunoelectrophoresis proved binding of serum amylase to lambda type IgA
From these results, the case was diagnosed as Gilbert's syndrome combined with macroamylasemia
